SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to frame a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your own experience; others may be impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. You can, however, give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether or not they are still living.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to store a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer a question will have experience as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to many persons; others may be impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces or answering them in detail. If there is not enough space to answer all the questions, please fill out the sheet of paper attached.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and who have personal experiences of the pioneer years whether they be in the province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or reply for a separate questionnaire.

Some of - Meeting Quebec in 1870

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens", etc.)
   It was in my teens.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

As the old saying goes, when you go west, you think you're going to school by the time you get there.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

A lady and visiting sir Maclean before I had heard of my mind. I'll tell you about the better opportunities in the west as they worry Red from living in Saskatchewan.

Signed Robert 1899
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other groups)? With my wife.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Canadian Pacific Railway

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.). We had a coach on the railway when we got to the prairie and had to deliver that night via a day late getting to Regina. We were only two hours behind schedule. We arrived at the train in Saskatchewan. That they needed a train then we made the next stop. The journey was very smooth to Saskatchewan.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? At my uncle's place until we settled down.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Seven miles N.W. of Saskatoon.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Working out $15.416 a month for six months of the year before coming to Saskatoon to work in the mills.

In 1902 I worked on the Fifth Elevator in Saskatoon. Build for Leslie & Wilson of Saskatoon and in Marching time I worked on George Brown's cattle that fall in 1902.
11. What was your family's decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it would be better.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a group (family, friends, or other groups)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Canadian Pacific Railway

In 1902 I worked on the Fifth Elevator in Saskatoon. Build by Beulah & Wilson of Saskatoon and in Marching time I worked on George Brown's outfit that fell in 1902.
